contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Vagrant shrew<ref name=msw3>{{MSW3 Hutterer | pages = 299}}</ref> | status = LC | status_system = iucn3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=iucn>{{IUCN2009.2|assessors=Matson, J., Woodman, N. & Reid, F.|year=2008|id= 41425|title= Sorex vagrans|downloaded=09 February 2010}}</ref> | image = VagrantShrew23.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammal]]ia | ordo = [[Soricomorpha]] | familia = [[Soricidae]] | genus = ''[[Sorex]]'' | species = '''''S. vagrans''''' | binomial = ''Sorex vagrans'' | binomial_authority = [[Spencer Fullerton Baird|Baird]], 1857 | range_map = Vagrant Shrew area.png | range_map_caption = Vagrant shrew range }} The '''vagrant shrew''' (''Sorex vagrans'') is a medium-sized [[North America]]n [[shrew]]. At one time, the [[montane shrew]] (''S. monticolus'') was considered to belong to the same species as this animal. ==Range== This animal is found in open and wooded areas in western [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] west of the [[Continental Divide]].<ref name=Burt>{{cite book|last=Burt|first=William H.|title=A Field Guide to Mammals: North America north of Mexico|year=1976|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-395-24082-4|pages=3}}</ref> ==Description== It is red brown in colour with grey underparts and a long tail which is sometimes paler in color underneath. During winter, its fur is dark brown. Its body is about {{convert|10|cm|in}} in length including a {{convert|4|cm|in}} long tail<ref name=Burt /> and it weighs about {{convert|6|g|oz}}. ===Behavior=== It often uses runways created by [[vole]]s. Its diet includes insects, [[earthworm]]s, [[salamander]]s, small mammals and some plant material. Predators of the vagrant shrew include [[owl]]s, snakes and [[mustelid]]s. This animal sometimes uses [[Animal echolocation|echolocation]] to orient itself in unfamiliar locations.<ref name=Buchler>{{cite journal|last=Buchler|first=E.R.|title=The use of echolocation by the wandering shrew (Sorex vagrans)|journal=Animal Behaviour|year=1976|month=November|volume=24|issue=4|pages=858â€“873|doi=10.1016/S0003-3472(76)80016-4|accessdate=10 October 2012}}</ref> This animal is active year-round, mainly at night. It is mainly solitary except during breeding which mainly occurs in the spring. The female has 1 or 2 litters of 3 to 8 young in a nest in a stump or under a log. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Soricomorpha|S2.}} [[Category:Sorex]] {{redtoothed-shrew-stub}}
